{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3101756,"name":"chrisrin","username":"chrisrin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chrisrin/{size}/160418_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-20T20:49:36.598Z","cooked":"

There have been a couple recent discussion threads from people asking what kind of raw materials they should buy. Aluminum tube + gusset construction is by far the most common, but what about channel, angle, etc. - when might they be better (for weight savings or other reasons)?

I found this article (one of a set on trailer-building) that has an interesting chart of beam profile characteristics if you scroll down a bit: Beam Shapes (or Beam Profile) In DIY Projects ‚Äì What Should I Use? (mechanicalelements.com)

One of the mentors on our team is a very experienced ME/EE/naval architect, and over the years he has regularly commented that tubes + gussets are overused and that channel & angle in combination with tube along with lap joints can be as good or better for many things. Example of the difference:
vs.

I assume there are other people/teams out there who think about this stuff‚Ä¶ Interested in your points of view when it comes to FRC applications. My own opinion (as someone who is still learning) is‚Ä¶ we use tube & gussets because it‚Äôs easy & it works, & it‚Äôs pretty easily teachable‚Ä¶ not necessarily because it‚Äôs always the best.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-20T20:49:56.389Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":154,"reads":300,"readers_count":299,"score":845.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"chrisrin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://mechanicalelements.com/select-beam-shapes-beam-profile/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Beam Shapes (or Beam Profile) In DIY Projects ‚Äì What Should I Use?","clicks":17}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3101759,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-20T21:03:32.226Z","cooked":"

Angle can work pretty well for some things. Actually have a robot from some time back that shakes out like this:
Drive base, 1x1 tube
Lift, 2x1 C-channel (x8, 2 welded together for a center piece)
Upper arm, 2" square tube and 2x1 channel
Braces/mounting, 1" angle

Any problems with the channel used on the lift flexing on the open side? I may not be envisioning it right; using channel probably means different design options.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-20T21:23:24.492Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":268,"readers_count":267,"score":73.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"chrisrin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3101777,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-20T22:13:02.677Z","cooked":"

Team 4618 made good use of aluminum unistrut in 2018 to make a light weight elevator stage. The c-shaped profile makes it easy to build a linear slider without so many bearings

FB_IMG_1668982145450960√ó640 79.3 KB

That said, there are so many good elevator kits now, this technique might be obsolete.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-20T22:13:02.677Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":245,"readers_count":244,"score":119.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/3230T36-3230T86/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":31},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/0/8/083f7ccca058cac1116dc84aa7065c05de99ce57.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3101778,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-20T22:13:16.720Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôll have to get some pictures later (read: remind me in a couple weeks), but no. I think we had more issues with bowing (the lift was rather strong and on at least one occasion managed to damage itself)‚Äìthe inside set looks like it was replaced at some point due to bow or something else.

For each side, the two center channels were welded back-to-back to form an I-beam. The outer pair were normal. 1/8" wall IIRC. Anodized (helps with aluminum, gets it a bit harder).

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-20T22:13:16.720Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":83.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28219,"username":"chrisrin","name":"chrisrin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chrisrin/{size}/160418_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/5","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3101909,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-21T05:15:27.224Z","cooked":"

I have definitely had good experience with both angle and channel, as well as tube, especially when not up against a tough weight limit and could go to 1/8" rather than 1/16" wall. It is a lot easier to put chain/belt runs and other mechanisms inside of channel than tube, and you get a ‚Äúfree‚Äù chain guard.

My favorite was our STEAMworks climber - a ratchet wrench on the shaft inside a bit of 2x1 C-channel merely needed to be kept from falling out with a velcro strap. Easy to set, easy to remove. Doing that with tubing would have required a good bit extra.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-21T05:15:27.224Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":191,"readers_count":190,"score":58.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/6","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3101999,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-21T17:03:18.029Z","cooked":"

As an ME, tubes are the strongest options for framing given a constant weight. Other shapes may have advantages in ease of attachment or strength in situations where they are not primarily carrying load from along their length.

L-channel and C-channel will have much higher wall thicknesses than tubes of the same weight, so their sections are less likely to deform in some (but not all) situations where loads are transferred from one face to another rather than end to end. For example if you are joining to flat plates an 90 degrees, an L will usually make a stronger joint than a tube.

Open sections are much easier to access for bolting to a single wall and in the case of thicker walls, local deformation and breakage around the fasteners are less likely. So if ease of assembly is a priority, and strength over long distances is not needed, use the C or L.

Sometimes you need weird shapes that can be cut from a C or L. We keep some 3‚Äùx1/4‚Äù L and other odd sections around despite using primary 1x1 and 1x2 thin walled tube because some times we can make a single bracket out of the big stock that would otherwise use several pieces of tube, small L brackets, and custom gussets. In these cases the final part looks closer to a billet part than a long extrusion.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-21T17:03:18.029Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":55.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/7","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3102001,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-21T17:07:48.305Z","cooked":"

In your pictured example, the tube joint is actually stronger if gussets are used on both sides, the joint shown with a channel could also be made with all tubes, but it would be much harder to assemble. Really using channels is usually about ease of assembly not strength. Very valid approach, but if you are trying to squeeze every last ounce out of a design tube are usually your friend.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-21T17:07:48.305Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":33.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/8","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3102002,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-21T17:09:08.394Z","cooked":"

Funnily enough this is basically what we did in 2018 and 2022 but we did it with 2x1 tubing with a slot cut in one wall.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-21T17:09:08.394Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":142,"readers_count":141,"score":33.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":22221,"username":"nuclearnerd","name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/9","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3102003,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-11-21T17:10:27.616Z","cooked":"

We used C-channel this past season as our outer-rail to support the ends of the shafts with our wheels. Worked well and allowed us to put a shaft-collar in there without worrying about rubbing against our bumpers. Would do it again.

We decided to support the other end of the shaft instead of cantilevering mainly because you have to have something backing the bumpers anyway, and that backing removes some of the ease-of-access you get from cantilevering.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-21T17:10:27.616Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":48.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3102005,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-21T17:13:48.703Z","cooked":"

We support our bumpers at the top so there is no loss of access to the wheels.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-11-21T17:13:48.703Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":131,"readers_count":130,"score":31.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":418284,"topic_slug":"using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/using-channel-angle-other-extrusions-beside-tube/418284/11","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3102012,"name":"Drakxii","username":"Drakxii","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-11-21T17:34:00.032Z","cooked":"

When using C-channel, make sure your team is using spacers or tool that limits torque (like a drill set to a lower torque setting), as my history with it is that students get over eager with it and will torque it down to a D-channel with just hand tools.
